Mar 22

From ‘Business Case’ to ‘Making the first sale’

The first 284 days of Stockphoto.com

Background

I launched Stockphoto.com in 2013 with money I had saved. You can read more here:

How to ask your wife for permission to spend $250,000 on a domain name
(aka “How Stockphoto.com started”)

Definitely not your average angel round.blog.stockphoto.com

Nov 30th, 2012 — I spot the auction on Flippa.com for Stockphoto.com and try my luck with the vendor. No response.

Fri, 30 Nov 2012 18:44:02 AEST
baselinej70:
Hi there blackstar, I apologise for the seemingly stupid question but may I ask if you would share your reserve price?

Dec 4th, 2012 — While researching the stock photography industry I stumble on this post (“10 ways to spot a dodgy agency”) from my future co-founder, Lee Torrens. Lee is the pre-eminent commentator via his blog, Microstock Diaries (he’s also the Head of Marketplace at Canva, but that’s different story for another day).

Dec 4th, 2012 — I put forth the business case to my wife seeking approval to purchase Stockphoto.com. Fortunately, it’s accepted and I’m still married.

Dec 7th, 2012 — I place a bid of $50,200 at the auction. Vendor accepts my bid and I become an approved bidder in the eyes of Flippa. I can freely bid/counter-bid without having to be vetted by the vendor.

Dec 8th, 2012- I am outbid when a $50,300 offer is tabled

Dec 11th, 2012 — I message the vendor:

Tue, 11 Dec 2012 9:33:48 AEST
    baselinej70:
    Hi there, have you had any trademark issues with the domain name?
    In the event that I am successful in purchasing the name from you, would you be amenable to a sale agreement (drafted up by my attorney) that protects me from future legal actions by retaining the benefit of the prior owner’s longstanding use and ownership of the name?
He responds:
    Tue, 11 Dec 2012 9:46:14 AEST
    blackstar_role:
    no trademark issues
    we have had this domain before even istockphoto
    in theory, yes, we would be open to tht sort of language in a contract of sale

Dec 11th, 2012 — I instruct my accountant to establish a new legal entity.

Dec 15th, 2012 — I commission David E. Weslow at Wiley Rein for the domain name purchase agreement (taking into account any potential trademark issues), terms of use, purchase agreement and photographer agreement.

Dec 24th, 2012 — I submit the $250,000 Buy-it-now price and it is accepted by the vendor.

Dec 26th, 2012 — I send the $250,000 via Bank Transfer to Escrow.com (along with deepest sigh ever sighed).

Dec 28th, 2012 — I gain possession of the Stockphoto.com domain name and organise an extended Skype session with the vendor, during which we discuss his hand registration of the domain name as well as his, ultimately, unsuccessful forays into microstock (as an extension to his existing and very successful rights-managed image business).

Jan 1st, 2013 — Domain transfer completes.

Jan 2nd, 2013 — I organise web hosting via LiquidWeb.

Jan 9th, 2013 — I install a Wordpress landing page with a Mailchimp sign-up form (allowing visitors to sign up to a list as either image purchaser, photographer or just kicking the tyres) and Google Analytics. I get my first sign-up almost straightaway. I send my wife an email saying “In the first 16 hours of life, our fourth child has had 17 people that gave up their email to demonstrate their interest”

Jan 11th, 2013 — CEO of Shutterstock, Jon Oringer, checks me out on LinkedIn. He accepts my offer to connect and I half-jokingly ask him if he planned to sue me. He replies that he was just interested to see who bought the domain name from the Flippa auction.

Jan 22nd, 2013 — Meet up with Miles Burke from Bam Creative to scope, price and schedule web development effort.

Feb 21st, 2013 — Laura Egerton (from Bam) is assigned to be the Project Manager for Stockphoto.com. I finalise the requirements and functional specs and development is kicked off.

Feb 28th, 2013 — Over 1,500 visitors sign up to our mailing list via the Mailchimp landing page.

May 25th, 2013 — Lee Torrens drops me an email making first contact.

May 29th, 2013 — I meet Lee Torrens in person in Sydney over a few beers. He tells me, very politely, that he’s not so sure about my initial SAAS business model. I decide to pivot to a more traditional agency model after some gnashing of teeth. Unbeknownst to him, I made up my mind that evening that he was going to be a co-founder of Stockphoto.com (whether he liked it or not).

Jun 7th, 2013 — Lee Torrens introduces me to Sergey Nivens (rockstar stock photographer).

Jul 7th, 2013 — Sergey Nivens agrees to sign up as Stockphoto.com’s first contributor!

Sep 9th, 2013 — Stockphoto.com slips quietly into Production.

Sep 10th, 2013 — Stockphoto.com makes its first sale, a $50 purchase.

TO BE CONTINUED….I thought I would document all these key events in my little adventure before I forgot them altogether :)
